description: Self-reported speed of muscle gain from training
rationale: Hypertrophy disruption = can't build; autophagy disruption = less catabolism = better retention

description: Tendency to carry muscle without training
rationale: MuRF1/2 regulate muscle mass; reduced autophagy preserves mass from breakdown
Muscle mass correlates with strength; less catabolism helps maintain strength
Fast-twitch fiber development requires hypertrophic signaling
Autophagy critical for mitochondrial quality control; hypertrophy less relevant for cardio
Mitophagy maintains healthy mitochondria for sustained aerobic performance
Autophagy essential for clearing damaged proteins post-exercise
Impaired autophagy = accumulation of damaged proteins = more soreness
Both pathways contribute to muscle quality control and repair mechanisms
Both hypertrophy and autophagy equally required for exercise adaptation
